However, when considering this pathway, it is important to keep in mind that individuals with BPD are more likely to have experienced sexual or physical assault (Lieb, et al., 2004) due to the same characteristics of the disorder. Thus, it is important to fairly and adequately weigh the evidence presented in an allegation of sexual assault.

The DSM-IV-TR (American Psychiatric Association, 2000) defines histrionic personality disorder as "pervasive and excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior" (p. 711). Prevalence estimates range from .6% to 2.9% of the general population (as cited in Lenzenweger et al., 2007; American Psychiatric Association, 2000). The primary diagnostic criteria of interest in this pathway are diagnostic criteria 1, 2, 5, 7, and 8. Other relevant behaviors include the tendency to play out stereotyped roles in their relationships with others; an intense desire for novelty and excitement; and the upset and depression that may follow periods in which they received little attention (American Psychiatric Association, 2000).

Filing a false allegation of sexual assault may serve to benefit individuals with histrionic personality disorder in several important ways. The sexualized behavior of individuals with histrionic personality disorder can lead to sexual relationships that may be used to seek attention (e.g., having sex with a person and telling all of their friends about it).
